2: Sperm fertilizes egg in the fallopian tube
Genetic material combines, determining baby's sex
Zygote begins cell division while traveling to uterus
3: The fertilized egg implants in the uterus
4: Two cell layers form that will develop into all organs
The primitive placenta is forming to nourish the baby
The amniotic and yolk sacs are forming to protect and support the embryo
5: The embryo has three layers that will form all organs and tissues
The neural tube (which becomes the brain and spinal cord) begins to form
6: Eyes, nose, mouth, and ears are beginning to form
7: The main parts of the eyes are beginning to form
The stomach, esophagus, liver, and pancreas start developing
The brain is forming three distinct areas and growing rapidly
8: The baby starts making small movements, visible on ultrasound
The respiratory system is developing with tiny breathing tubes
A network of nerves is forming and connecting to muscles and organs
9: Tooth buds are forming inside the gums
The baby's heart now has four chambers and beats rapidly
The placenta is developing and starts producing essential hormones
10: The baby's eyes are fully formed and covered by closed eyelids
Teeth are starting to harden and connect to the jawbone
The brain is growing rapidly, and the baby can now move limbs and fingers
11: The baby's fingers and toes are fully separated and growing
Vital organs are in place and starting to function
The baby's genitals begin to develop
12: The baby can open and close hands and curl toes
Tiny fingernails are growing on fingers and toes
The intestines are developing and will soon move into the abdomen
13: The baby swallows amniotic fluid and produces urine
Meconium is forming in the baby's bowels
Bones and teeth are beginning to harden and grow denser
14: The baby is making facial expressions and sucking movements
Hair follicles are forming, soon to sprout fine hair
The baby is active with flexible hands and feet
15: Taste buds are forming and connecting to the brain
The baby moves all joints and limbs but movement isn't felt yet
Facial features and limbs are well defined; baby begins yawning
16: The baby's skin is thin and translucent, and will thicken over time
Hair follicles on the scalp are forming a lifelong pattern
The heart is pumping around 25 quarts of blood daily and growing stronger
17: The baby's skeleton is hardening from cartilage to bone
The umbilical cord is growing stronger and thicker to support nutrient flow
Sweat glands are developing, and skin layers will soon be fully formed
18: Facial features including ears, nose, lips, and hair are recognizable
Lungs develop tiny bronchioles and respiratory sacs
Sex organs are formed and visible on ultrasound
19: Permanent fingerprints and toeprints have formed
The brain is developing areas for all five senses
A protective waxy coating called vernix caseosa covers the baby's skin
20: Baby hiccups may begin and are normal
Taste buds can send signals to the brain
Baby swallows molecules from amniotic fluid, possibly influencing future taste preferences
21: The baby's taste buds are working and respond to flavors in amniotic fluid
The sucking reflex is developing; thumb sucking may be visible on ultrasound
The baby's skin is wrinkled, translucent, and appears red due to blood vessels
22: Baby's hair and eyebrows are visible, along with fine lanugo on the body
The baby can hear internal sounds like your heartbeat and digestion
A layer of fat is forming under the skin, though the baby is still skinny
23: The baby can hear external sounds and recognizes the mother's voice
Digestive movements begin as practice despite no food intake
Baby movements become stronger, evolving into gentle kicks and jabs
24: Lung sacs are growing to improve oxygen exchange
The baby is gaining weight but still has thin, translucent skin
The baby practices facial movements like raising eyebrows
25: The baby is gaining fat and smoothing out wrinkled skin
Hair is growing, showing color and texture
The baby cycles through REM and non-REM sleep regularly
26: The baby practices breathing by inhaling and exhaling amniotic fluid
The baby hears sounds and may respond with movement and facial expressions
In boys, testicles begin descending into the scrotum
27: The baby can open and close their eyes and may respond to light
Fetal hiccups are common and normal
The lungs are producing surfactant to prepare for breathing after birth
28: The baby's brain is growing rapidly, developing deep grooves
Senses like hearing, smell, and touch are functioning
The autonomic nervous system begins regulating body temperature and breathing
29: Bones are hardening with daily calcium deposits
Myelin begins forming to protect the baby's nerves
Lungs produce surfactant to prepare for breathing after birth
30: Skin cells start producing melanin to determine skin color
Hair on the head thickens; lanugo begins to disappear
The baby can open eyes and see dim shapes
31: The baby is gaining fat to prepare for birth
Movements like stretching and kicking indicate good health
Brain growth accelerates, forming deep grooves for more surface area
32: The baby stores minerals like iron and calcium for early life
Lungs are nearly fully formed; baby practices breathing amniotic fluid
Genitalia are fully formed; testicles begin descending in boys, ovaries in place for girls
33: Skull bones remain flexible to help the baby pass through the birth canal
Skin is becoming smoother and less translucent as the baby gains fat
Movements continue but may feel different as the baby shifts position
34: Fingernails have grown to fingertips; toenails will reach toes by week 38
Baby's arms and legs are filling out and becoming chubby
The baby responds to sounds, light, and touch; ears nearly fully formed
35: Amniotic fluid cushions the baby, peaking around 36 weeks before decreasing
Kidneys are fully developed; baby urinates into amniotic fluid; meconium builds up
Distinct sleep and wake cycles begin, affecting baby's movement
36: The baby's lungs are fully ready to breathe air after birth
Bones are hardening but still softer than an adult's
The baby is shedding lanugo and vernix, forming meconium in the intestines
37: Many babies have a full head of hair that may change color and texture after birth
Baby's eye color may change during the first year
The baby is gaining weight and developing fat to help keep warm
38: Fingernails and toenails are fully formed and may need trimming after birth
The baby has a smooth layer of fat and has mostly shed lanugo
Hair on the head may be thicker and more visible
39: The baby continues gaining fat to regulate body temperature after birth
Average length is about 20 inches and weight just over 7 pounds
The baby has a strong grasp, coordinated reflexes, and can see faces up close
40: The baby typically weighs 7-8 pounds and is about 20 inches long
Newborn skin is reddish-purple, changing to pink as circulation matures
Soft spots (fontanels) on the skull allow flexibility during birth and growth
The baby is ready to meet you!
41: The baby is considered late term and may be larger than average
Most of the protective vernix coating has been lost
Estimated size is about 8.35 pounds and 20.39 inches long
